Caption:
It was just a year ago when the phrase ‚Äú I can‚Äôt breathe‚Äù became a metaphor for the systemic racism people of color live with every day of their lives - unable to take a full deep breath knowing they are safe and free ‚Äìunlike those of us whose privilege is so deeply embedded in us we don‚Äôt even see it.

We know that at least today, in this moment, justice has prevailed. And make no mistake. This is just the beginning of the work. But it is a beginning.

Today we took a step. There is so much to do but our society can exhale ever so slightly knowing that we have taken a step on the path toward justice.

I am committed to walking that path toward justice with intention. I believe that systemic change is possible, and while I will stumble along the way, I am determined to learn, to do better, to understand my privilege and to use it to make the world a more equitable place.

And a young girl with the presence of mine to capture that 9 minutes of video, she is a hero. That's what leadership looks like. It's time for all of us to follow her lead. #leadership #justiceforgeorgefloyd #justicematters #racialjustice

Name: Nicole Clark Consulting
Caption:
Navigating the pandemic as an introvert (where too much solitude is draining) or as an extrovert (where social distancing from friends and family has taken its toll) has its pros and cons.

One way to balance your introvert and extrovert sides is to identify self care activities that meet the needs of both sides separately and together.

Grab a sheet of paper, something to write with, and create your introvert/extrovert self care plan. Swipe through for ideas: 

SECOND PIC: Think of a Venn diagram, where two circles overlap in the middle. Draw out your circles and label the left side as INTROVERT and the right as EXTROVERT. In each circle, list self care activities and/or people you can count on that speak to either side. What would an introverted or extroverted self care activity look like during the pandemic?

THIRD PIC: Now, list the overlap section as BOTH. In this section, list activities that you could do by yourself but can be shared with another person. This helps you create a self care plan that is well-rounded. Here's one example.

Create a self care plan that honors your solitude while also exploring ways to connect with others. Try this out and let me know how it goes.
